sentences.sentence: “I noticed that the soldiers used always to lose and the civilians to win.
These prison guards had done little else than play cards ever since they had been at the Andamans, while the others just played to pass the time.
Night after night the soldiers got up poorer men.
Major Sholto was the hardest hit. He used to pay in notes and gold at first, but soon he was writing big I.O.Us.
He would win for a few hands, and then the luck would run against him worse than ever.
He took to drinking more than was good for him.
One night he lost even more heavily than usual. I was sitting in my hut( 小屋 ) when he and Captain Morstan came stumbling( 蹒跚而行 ) along on the way to their quarters.
They were close friends, those two, and never far apart.
The major was raving about( 激愤地说 ) his losses.
‘I’m finished, Morstan,’ he was saying, as they passed my hut( 小屋 ). ‘I am a ruined man.’
‘Me too’, said the other, slapping( 拍 ) him upon the shoulder. ‘If we can’t pay the money back, we will be thrown out of( 逐出 ) the army in disgrace( 不光彩 ).’
I saw my chance. I told them the story of the treasure—with small changes so that they could not find it—
and told them that if the other members of the Sign of Four agreed, we could give them a share of the treasure that would not only pay off( 还清 ) their debts but make them rich men.
I insisted that the others be consulted, which they did not like but had to agree to.
The matter ended in a second meeting, at which Mahomet Singh, Abdullah Khan, and Dost Akbar were all present.
We talked the matter over, and at last we came to an arrangement( 达成协议 ).
We were to provide both the officers with charts of the part of the Agra fort( 城堡 ) and mark the place in the wall where the treasure was hid.
Major Sholto was to go to India to test our story.
If he found the box he was to leave it there, to send out a small yacht( 游艇 ) with supplies for a voyage and leave it tied up( 停靠 ) at a nearby island, and finally to return to his duties.
Captain Morstan was then to apply for leave of absence( 休假 ), to meet us at Agra, and there we were to have a final division of the treasure, he taking the major’s share as well as his own.
All this we sealed by the most solemn( 郑重的 ) oaths( 誓言 ) that the mind could think or the lips utter( 说出 ).
I sat up all night with paper and ink, and by the morning I had the two charts all ready, signed with the sign of four—that is, of Abdullah, Akbar, Mahomet, and myself.
Well, I’ll make it as short as I can. The villain( 恶棍 ) Sholto went off to India, but he never came back again.
Captain Morstan showed me his name among a list of passengers in one of the boats to England very shortly afterwards( 以后 ).
His uncle had died, leaving him a fortune, and he had left the army, yet he could stoop( 卑劣到去做 ) to treat five men as he had treated us.
Morstan went over to Agra shortly afterwards( 以后 ), and found, as we expected, that the treasure was indeed gone.
From that day I lived only for vengeance( 复仇 ). To escape, to track down Sholto, to have my hand upon his throat—that was my one thought.
Even the Agra treasure had come to be a smaller thing in my mind than the killing of Sholto.
Well, I have set my mind on many things in this life, and I have done every one of them. But it was weary( 感到厌烦的 ) years before my time came.
I have told you that I had picked up( 学会 ) something of medicine.
One day when Dr. Somerton was down with a fever, a little Andaman Islander was picked up( 带回 ) by some prisoners in the woods.
He was sick to death, and had gone to a lonely place to die.
I took him in, and after a couple of months I got him cured and able to walk.
He took a liking to me then, and would hardly go back to his woods, but was always hanging about( 闲荡 ) my hut( 小屋 ).
I learned a little of his language from him, and this made him all the fonder of me.
Tonga—for that was his name—was a fine boatman, and owned a big, roomy canoe( 独木舟 ) of his own.
When I found that he was devoted to( 对...忠诚 ) me and would do anything to serve me, I saw my chance of escape.
I talked it over with him. He was to bring his boat round on a certain night to an old wharf( 码头 ) which was never guarded, and there he was to pick me up( 接走我 ).
I gave him directions to have several gourds of water and a lot of yams, coconuts, and sweet potatoes.
He was loyal( 忠诚的 ) and true, was little Tonga. No man ever had a more faithful mate( 同伴 ).
At the night named he had his boat at the wharf( 码头 ).
Tonga had brought all his possessions with him, his arms and his gods.
Among other things, he had a long bamboo spear, and some Andaman mats made out of palm( 棕榈树 ) leaves, with which I made a sort of sail.
For ten days we were sailing about, trusting to luck, and on the eleventh we were picked up( 带上 ) by a trading boat which was going from Singapore on a pilgrimage( 朝圣之旅 ) to Mecca.
They were a strange crowd, but Tonga and I soon managed to settle down( 安定下来 ) among them.
They had one very good quality: they let you alone and asked no questions.
Well, if I were to tell you all the adventures that my little friend and I went through, you would not thank me, for I would have you here until the sun was shining.
Here and there we drifted( 漂泊 ) about the world, something always turning up to keep us from London. All the time, however, I never lost sight of( 忘记 ) my purpose.
I would dream of Sholto at night. A hundred times I have killed him in my sleep.
At last, however, some three or four years ago, we found ourselves in England.
I had no great difficulty in finding where Sholto lived, and I set to work to discover whether he had sold the treasure, or if he still had it.
I made friends with someone who could help me—I name no names, for I don’t want to get anyone else in trouble—and I soon found that he still had the jewels.
Then I tried to get at him in many ways; but he was pretty sly( 狡猾的 ), and had always two prize-fighters( 职业拳击手 ), besides his sons and his Indian servant, on guard over him.”
